facts.text: Writ Petitions Nos. 187 and 188 of 1970 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Writ Petitions Nos. 187 and 188 of 1970. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for enforcement of the fundamental rights.

facts.text: Petitions filed by owners of two residential buildings in the city of Bombay, neither dilapidated nor in dangerous condition due to recent construction.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions by owners of two residential buildings, in the city of Bombay, neither of which is, by reason of its having been recently companystructed, either dilapidated or in dangerous companydition, challenge the validity

facts.text: Bombay Building Repairs and Reconstruction Board Act, XLVII of 1969 challenged.

anchor.surface_text: ...dangerous companydition, challenge the validity of the Bombay Building Repairs and Reconstruction Board Act, XLVII of 1969.

facts.text: Act brought into force on October 1, 1969; cess payable became operative from November 1, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was brought into force on October 1, 1969 and the cess payable thereunder became operative as from November 1, 1970.

facts.text: Act declared temporary by s. 14, expires on December 31, 1979.

anchor.surface_text: The Act by s. 1 4  is declared to be a temporary one and would expire on December 31, 1979.

facts.text: Structural repairs defined in s. 2(s) as repairs or replacement of decayed, cracked structural components.

anchor.surface_text: Structural repairs are defined by s. 2  s  as meaning repairs or replacement of decayed, cracked, or out of plumb structural companyponents of a building or any substantial part thereof or any part to which the occupiers have companymon access,

facts.text: Board established under Ss. 3 and 4 with duties under Ss. 21 and 22 including structural repairs, acquisition, reconstruction, transit camps.

anchor.surface_text: Ss. 3 and 4 provide for the establishment and companyposition of the Bombay Building Repairs and Reconstruction Board. Ss. 21 and 22 lay down the duties, powers and functions of the Board including the power to carry out structural as also tenantable repairs,

facts.text: Cess levied under s. 27 on buildings and lands at prescribed rates; owner share 10% of rateable value, recoverable from tenant.

anchor.surface_text: S. 27 provides that subject to the provisions of S. 28 there shall be levied a tax on buildings and lands called the Bombay Buildings Repairs and Reconstruction Cess at the rate of so many percentum of the rateable value of the companycerned property as is prescribed therefor under the Schedule to the Act.

facts.text: Act applies to three categories of buildings per s. 29; Schedule provides rates varying by category and if structurally repaired.

anchor.surface_text: S. 29 lays down three categories of buildings to which the Act applies. The Schedule to the Act provides different rates at which buildings falling in each category would be subject to the cess.

facts.text: Proceeds of cess credited to consolidated fund then transferred to Board's fund.

anchor.surface_text: The proceeds of the cess would be first credited to the ,consolidated fund of the State and thereafter under an appropriation duly made by law in that behalf would be transferred to a fund,

facts.text: Petitioners challenge Act under Art. 19(1)(f) as unreasonable restriction on sound buildings; violates Art. 14 by treating unequals as equals; exemptions arbitrary.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the petitioners challenged the validity of the Act principally under three heads  1  that in the companytext of the ,existing legislation, i.e., the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, III of 1888 and the Bombay Rent Control Act, 1947, the imposition of a cess on residential buildings,

facts.text: City Corporation survey in 1956 of residential buildings: 36,000 total, 17,490 built prior to 1905.

anchor.surface_text: The survey revealed that there were within the city 36,000 residential buildings, of which 17,490 were built prior to 1905.

facts.text: Survey categories: future life details - 5,081 with 5 years, 3,549 with 6-10 years, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The report further revealed that of the said 17,490 buildings,  a  5,081 of them had a future life of five years only,  b  3,549 a future life of six to ten years,  c  3,286 a future life of eleven to fifteen years,

facts.text: Total families in buildings needing substantial repairs: 1,04,270, 80% in one room tenements.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of families living in buildings which imminently required substantial repairs, if they were to survive, came to 1,04,270, 80 of whom were occupying one room tenements.

facts.text: Bedekar Committee appointed by State Government in 1965 to examine building collapse problem.

anchor.surface_text: In 1965, the State Government appointed the Bedekar Committee to examine the problem.

facts.text: Government published proposals on June 3, 1968 for legislation to prevent collapses.

anchor.surface_text: On June 3, 1968 the Government Published certain proposals for eliciting public opinion for a legislation to prevent companylapses and salvaging dilapidated structures.

facts.text: Buildings categorized A (pre Sept 1, 1940), B (1940-1950), C (1951 to Act commencement).

anchor.surface_text: Sec. 29 divides the buildings so taxed into categories A, B and C. Buildings built prior to September 1. 1940 fall into category Al. those build between September 1, 1940 and December 31, 1950 fall into category B

facts.text: Cess rates: Category A 25% basic, 40% if repaired; B 20%/30%; C 15%/20%.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Schedule, category A buildings are charged at the rate of 25 of the rateable value and at 4 if any building in that category is structurally repaired by the Board.

facts.text: Owner pays 10% of cess, recovers balance from tenant via rent increase.

anchor.surface_text: The first is S. 27 4  under which an owner who is required to pay the cess pays only 10 of the rateable value of his building and is entitled to recover the balance from the tenant

facts.text: S. 23 of Bombay Rents Act suspended; tenant responsible for tenantable repairs per Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Court holds Act valid; petitions dismissed, no costs.

arguments.claim: No quid pro quo required; tax not benefit-based

anchor.surface_text: The levy of the cess under s. 27 of the Act is not based on the principle of qid pro quo. Its object is not to repair all residential premises, but to preserve and prolong their lives

arguments.claim: Act valid; petitions dismissed

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above, the Act has to be held valid and the petitions unsustainable. Accordingly, the petitions are dismissed but in the circumstances of the case there will no be any order of costs.

holdings.text: The Act has to be held valid and the petitions unsustainable.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above, the Act has to be held valid and the petitions unsustainable. Accordingly, the petitions are ,dismissed but in the circumstances of the case there will number be any order of companyts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: After examining challenges under Arts. 14 and 19(1)(f), classifications, public purpose, and exemptions, court finds no violations.

holdings.text: Both the purpose of the cess and its use are without doubt for public purpose.

anchor.surface_text: Both the purpose of the cess and its use are without doubt for public purpose. The purpose is to prevent companylapses and the suffering they must cause including rendering several persons homeless, a companydition accentuated by the demand for accommodation outrunning the supply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cess prevents collapses, preserves housing stock amid shortage; incidental benefits to some owners do not negate public purpose; cites US authorities and doctrine.

holdings.text: The classification of buildings into three categories is based on their age and the construction current during the periods of their erection. It is, therefore, based on an intelligible differentia and is closely related to the objects of the legislation. There is, therefore, no question of unequals being treated as equals.

anchor.surface_text: The classification of buildings into three categories is based, as already stated, on their age and the construction current during the periods of their erection. It is, therefore, based on an intelligible differentia and is closely related to the objects, of the legislation. There is, therefore, numberquestion of unequals being treated as equals, as each building in respect of which the cess is payable falls within the surveillance of the Board and has to be structurally repaired if the need were to arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Categories A,B,C grounded in surveys and reports on age/construction risks; satisfies twin test of intelligible differentia with rational nexus to preventing collapses; no quid pro quo needed.

holdings.text: The provisions for exempting them cannot be held as violative of the equal protection clause.

anchor.surface_text: Since these buildings forming separate classes by themselves form the tenanted residential premises, the provisions for exempting them cannot be held as violative of the equal protection clause.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Each exempted class (e.g., co-op societies, licensees, owner-occupied) distinct due to different legal relations, no Rent Act applicability; rational and consonant with objects.

holdings.text: The levy of the cess under s. 27 of the Act is not based on the principle of quid pro quo.

anchor.surface_text: The levy of the cess under s. 27 of the Act is number based on the principle of qid pro quo. Its object is number to repair all residential premises, but to preserve and prolong their lives

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax general levy for public purpose of averting collapses via Board surveillance/repairs, not individual benefit; distributed owner-tenant; distinguishes precedents like Moopil Nair.

holdings.text: The taxing statute is as much subject to Art. 14 as any other statute.

anchor.surface_text: The taxing statute is as much subject to Art. 14 as any other statute. T. Moopil Nair v. Kerala 1 , Raja Jagannath v. U. P 2 , East India Tobacco Co. v. Andhra Pradesh 8 , Khandige Sham Bhatt v. Agricultural Income Tax officer 4

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Art.14 to tax but allows wide classification leeway if twin test met; cites multiple SC precedents.

holdings.text: A Legislature does not have to tax everything in order to tax something.

anchor.surface_text: It is well recognised that a Legislature does number have to tax everything in order to tax something. It can pick and choose districts, objects, persons, methods and even rates of taxation as long as it does so reasonably 2 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Permits prioritization (residential over non-residential, existing over new) based on urgency/feasibility from reports.
